example.title: Determining a basis for an orthogonal complement
example.p: Let's carry out the example explored in , where we considered the space V = \matrixring_{2 \times 2}(\R) equipped with the inner product \inprod{A}{B} = \trace(\utrans{B} A) , and the subspace U of all upper triangular matrices whose upper-right entry is equal to its trace.

example.title: Determining a basis for an orthogonal complement in a complex space
example.p: Consider space \C^4 with the complex dot product, and subspace W = \Span \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), (1,-1,\ci,\ci) \bigr\} . Let \uvec{w}_1,\uvec{w}_2 represent the two spanning vectors above.

To be in \orthogcmp{W}, an arbitrary vector \uvec{z} = (z_1,z_2,z_3,z_4) in \C^4 must be orthogonal to each of \uvec{w}_1,\uvec{w}_2. So compute
\dotprod{\uvec{z}}{\uvec{w}_1} \amp = z_1 + z_2 - z_3 \ci - z_4 \ci \text{,} \dotprod{\uvec{z}}{\uvec{w}_2} \amp = z_1 - z_2 - z_3 \ci - z_4 \ci .

aside.title: Remember
aside.p: The complex dot product involves taking the complex conjugate of the second vector.

example.p:
Setting the above expressions to be equal to zero for orthogonality leads to homogeneous system
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 1 \amp -\ci \amp -\ci \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp -\ci \amp -\ci \end{array}\right] \qquad\rowredarrow\qquad \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -\ci \amp -\ci \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] . So z_3,z_4 are free, z_2 = 0, and z_1 = z_3 \ci + z_4 \ci , so that a typical vector in \orthogcmp{W} can be described parametrically as \uvec{z} = (s \ci + t \ci, 0, s, t) .

aside.title: Note
aside.p: Parameters s,t represent arbitrary complex values.

example.p: Finally, the above parametric expression for elements of \orthogcmp{W} leads to \orthogcmp{W} = \Span \bigl\{ (\ci, 0, 1, 0), (\ci, 0, 0, 1) \bigr\} .

subsection.title: Expansion relative to an orthogonal basis
subsection.p: Here we will provide an example of using the pattern of (discussed in ) to express a vector as a linear combination of orthogonal basis vectors.

example.p:
Consider V = \poly_2(\R) equipped with inner product \inprod{p}{q} = \integral{-1}{1}{p(x) q(x)}{x} . The collection
p_1(x) \amp = x + 1, \amp p_2(x) \amp = x^2 - x, \amp p_3(x) \amp = 5 x^2 + x - 2
forms an orthogonal basis \basisfont{B} for V.

aside.title: Check your understanding
aside.p: Compute the three variations of \inprod{p_i}{p_j} necessary to verify the claim that these vectors are orthogonal.

example.p: What is the coordinate vector \rmatrixOf{q}{B} for q(x) = 3 x^2 + 3 x + 3 ?

Compute
\inprod{q}{p_1} \amp = \integral{-1}{1}{(3 x^2 + 3 x + 3)(x + 1)}{x} = 10 \text{,} \inprod{q}{p_2} \amp = \integral{-1}{1}{(3 x^2 + 3 x + 3)(x^2 - x)}{x} = \frac{6}{5} \text{,} \inprod{q}{p_3} \amp = \integral{-1}{1}{(3 x^2 + 3 x + 3)(5 x^2 + x - 2)}{x} = 2 \text{.}
We also need the norms
\norm{p_1}^2 \amp = \inprod{p_1}{p_1} = \integral{-1}{1}{(x + 1)^2}{x} = \frac{8}{3} \text{,} \norm{p_2}^2 \amp = \inprod{p_2}{p_2} = \integral{-1}{1}{(x^2 - x)^2}{x} = \frac{16}{15} \text{,} \norm{p_3}^2 \amp = \inprod{p_3}{p_3} = \integral{-1}{1}{(5 x^2 + x - 2)^2}{x} = \frac{16}{3} \text{.}
Putting these together, we have
q(x) \amp = \frac{\inprod{q}{p_1}}{\norm{p_1}^2} \, p_1(x) + \frac{\inprod{q}{p_2}}{\norm{p_2}^2} \, p_2(x) + \frac{\inprod{q}{p_3}}{\norm{p_3}^2} \, p_3(x)
\amp = \frac{10}{8/3} \cdot p_1(x) + \frac{6/5}{16/15} \cdot p_2(x) + \frac{2}{16/3} \cdot p_3(x)
\amp = \frac{15}{4} \cdot p_1(x) + \frac{9}{8} \cdot p_2(x) + \frac{3}{8} \cdot p_3(x)
, so that \rmatrixOf{q}{B} = \left( \frac{15}{4}, \frac{9}{8}, \frac{3}{8} \right) .

example.title: Producing an orthogonal basis
example.p:
Consider V = \poly_2(\R) equipped with inner product \inprod{p}{q} = \integral{0}{1}{p(x) q(x)}{x} . Begin with the standard basis \basisfont{S} = \{ 1, x, x^2 \} . Following the process, set e_1(x) = 1 . In order to compute e_2(x), first compute
\inprod{x}{e_1} = \integral{0}{1}{x \cdot 1}{x} = \frac{1}{2} \text{,} \norm{e_1}^2 = \inprod{e_1}{e_1} = \integral{0}{1}{1^2}{x} = 1 \text{.}
Then we set
e_2(x) = x - \frac{\inprod{x}{e_1}}{\norm{e_1}^2} \, e_1(x) = x - \frac{1/2}{1} \cdot 1 = x - \frac{1}{2} . Computing e_3(x) will require quite a few more calculations:
\inprod{x^2}{e_1} = \integral{0}{1}{x^2 \cdot 1}{x} = \frac{1}{3} \text{,} \inprod{x^2}{e_2} = \integral{0}{1}{x^2 \left(x - \frac{1}{2}\right)}{x} = \frac{1}{12} \text{,} \norm{e_2}^2 = \inprod{e_1}{e_1} = \integral{0}{1}{\left(x - \frac{1}{2}\right)^2}{x} = \frac{1}{12} \text{.}
Using these results, compute
e_3(x) \amp = x^2 - \left( \frac{\inprod{x^2}{e_1}}{\norm{e_1}^2} \, e_1(x) + \frac{\inprod{x^2}{e_2}}{\norm{e_2}^2} \, e_2(x) \right)
\amp = x^2 - \left( \frac{1/3}{1} \cdot 1 + \frac{1/12}{1/12} \cdot \left(x - \frac{1}{2}\right) \right)
\amp = x^2 - x + \frac{1}{6}
. We know have orthogonal basis \basisfont{B} = \left\{ 1, x - \frac{1}{2}, x^2 - x + \frac{1}{6} \right\} . If we would like an orthonormal basis, we need one further calculation:
\norm{e_3}^2 = \inprod{e_3}{e_3} = \integral{0}{1}{\left(x^2 - x + \frac{1}{6}\right)^2}{x} = \frac{1}{180} . Using \sqrt{12} = 2\sqrt{3} and \sqrt{180} = 6\sqrt{5}, we can normalize to
\basisfont{B}' = \left\{ \frac{e_1(x)}{\norm{e_1}}, \frac{e_2(x)}{\norm{e_2}}, \frac{e_3(x)}{\norm{e_3}} \right\} = \{ 1, 2 \sqrt{3} \, x - \sqrt{3}, 6\sqrt{5} \, x^2 - 6\sqrt{5} \, x + \sqrt{5} \} .

example.title: Producing an orthogonal basis for a complex inner product space
example.p: Let's apply the process to \C^4, but starting with the basis \basisfont{B}_0 = \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), (1,-1,\ci,\ci), (\ci, 0, 1, 0), (\ci, 0, 0, 1) \bigr\} , which is made up of the basis vectors for W and \orthogcmp{W} from .

aside.title: Remember
aside.p: The complex dot product involves taking the complex conjugate of the second vector.

example.p:
Normally, we would now set \uvec{e}_2 to be
\uvec{w}_2 - \frac{\inprod{\uvec{w}_2}{\uvec{e}_1}}{\norm{\uvec{e}_1}^2} \, \uvec{e}_1 = (1,-1,\ci,\ci) - \frac{2}{4} (1,1,\ci,\ci) = \left(\frac{1}{2}, -\frac{3}{2}, \frac{\ci}{2}, \frac{\ci}{2} \right) . However, scalar multiples do not affect orthogonality, so let's clear the fractions by multiplying by 2, giving \uvec{e}_2 = ( 1, -3, \ci, \ci ) .

From here, we already know from
that \uvec{w}_3,\uvec{w}_4 are in \orthogcmp{W} so they will produce inner products of 0 against both \uvec{e}_1,\uvec{e}_2. This means the formulas for \uvec{e}_3,\uvec{e}_4 in the process will reduce to
\uvec{e}_3 \amp = \uvec{w}_3 - (\zerovec + \zerovec) \text{,} \amp \uvec{e}_4 \amp = \uvec{w}_4 - \left( \zerovec + \zerovec + \frac{\inprod{\uvec{w}_4}{\uvec{e}_3}}{\norm{\uvec{e}_3}^2} \, \uvec{e}_3 \right)
So using \uvec{e}_3 = \uvec{w}_3, calculate
\inprod{\uvec{w}_4}{\uvec{e}_3} = \dotprod{\uvec{w}_4}{\uvec{e}_3} = -\ci^2 + 0 + 0 + 0 = 1 \text{,}
\norm{\uvec{e}_3}^2 = \dotprod{\uvec{e}_3}{\uvec{e}_3} = -\ci^2 + 1 = 2
, from which we would normally set \uvec{e}_4 to be
\uvec{e}_4 \amp = \uvec{w}_4 - \frac{\inprod{\uvec{w}_4}{\uvec{e}_3}}{\norm{\uvec{e}_3}^2} \, \uvec{e}_3
\amp = (\ci, 0, 0, 1) - \frac{1}{2} \, (\ci, 0, 1, 0)
\amp = \left( \frac{\ci}{2}, 0, - \frac{1}{2}, 1 \right)
, but again we will clear fractions to obtain \uvec{e}_4 = (\ci, 0, -1, 2) . Putting all four vectors together gives us orthogonal basis \basisfont{B} = \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), ( 1, -3, \ci, \ci ), (\ci, 0, 1, 0), (\ci, 0, -1, 2) \bigr\} .

subsection.title: Obtaining an orthogonal complement using the Gram-Schmidt process
subsection.p: As discussed in , orthogonal bases tell us about subspaces and their complements. Since the Gram-Schmidt process is our main tool for obtaining orthogonal bases, we can use the process to determine orthogonal complements.

example.p: Now we'll revisit , where we considered the subspace W = \Span \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), (1,-1,\ci,\ci) \bigr\} of \C^4.

In , we created an orthogonal basis for \C^4 by applying the Gram-Schmidt process to an initial basis formed by joining a basis for W with a basis for \orthogcmp{W}. So we could obtain orthogonal bases for both W,\orthogcmp{W} by splitting that orthogonal \C^4 basis apart. However, in this example we will proceed as if we did not initially know any basis for \orthogcmp{W}.

The above basis for W can be enlarged into a basis for \C^4 by including two of the standard basis vectors:
\basisfont{B}_0 = \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), (1,-1,\ci,\ci), (0,0,1,0), (0,0,0,1) \bigr\} . Applying the process to \basisfont{B}_0 (and clearing fractions along the way) results in orthogonal basis
\basisfont{B} = \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), ( 1, -3, \ci, \ci ), (\ci, 0, 2, -1), (\ci, 0, 0, 1) \bigr\} . As \dim W was 2 in the first place, similarly to we can split \basisfont{B} in two to obtain an orthogonal basis for each of W,\orthogcmp{W}:
\basisfont{B}_W \amp = \bigl\{ (1,1,\ci,\ci), ( 1, -3, \ci, \ci ) \bigr\} \text{,} \amp \basisfont{B}_{\orthogcmp{W}} \amp = \bigl\{ (\ci, 0, 2, -1), (\ci, 0, 0, 1) \bigr\} .

subsection.title: An infinite orthogonal set
subsection.p: In , we showed that the sine and cosine functions are orthogonal with respect to a certain inner product on a space of continuous functions. We can extend that orthogonal pair into an infinite orthogonal set by varying the frequency of the sine and cosine functions.

example.title: An infinite orthogonal set of sines and cosines
example.p: Since all possible combinations of different functions from S evaluate to zero in the inner product, S is an orthogonal set.
